data.text: What are My Options for Durable, Good-Rolling Bikepacking Tyres?

hey guys, So, I have just learnt that the schwalbe G-one allround offers 0 puncture protection. To me that is what schwalbe stands for. I can't go tubeless either. So, what are my option if I would like to buy durable, good rolling bikepacking tyres (700√ó40c) that are not super heavy and offer punture protection (something that could live up to what the G-one allround offers)? Thank you. Update: thank you all for the valuable information. Got the marathon almotion eventually.
Rising my G Ones for about 2000km now and only had 1 puncture.
data.author: Hauke Kottek

data.text: Is it the super ground one?
data.author: Gabe Rivers

data.text: Yes, the Evolution Super Ground TLE. Had them on a touring setup with panniers. The one on the back wore if very fast compared to the other. But for lighter bike packing they are perfect for me.
data.author: Hauke Kottek

data.text: Oh and the puncture was on a road where others with racing bikes had several punctures a day!
data.author: Hauke Kottek

data.text: Yeah I'm running tubeless and no puntures. I have seen the occasional tell tale white blob of white fluid where it has automatically plugged a pin hole from a sharp object.
data.author: Craig Ferguson

data.text: These are what I just swapped my G ones to. They came with my bike and they are terrible puncture wise.
data.author: Tony Campbell

data.text: how does that help? üòÖ
data.author: Gabe Rivers

data.text: no I mean the g ones are terrible. Re fuse means refuse to puncture
data.author: Tony Campbell

data.text: ah, OK. Gotcha.:)
data.author: Gabe Rivers

data.text: Why can't you go Tubeless? I'm using 2.25" G1 at the moment with 5000km of use (about 3000km of those off-road) with zero punctures thus far.
data.author: Peter Gostelow

data.text: OK. That is promising. I am still trying to figure out the differences within the G one allround family. Which one do you have? Super ground or raceguard?
data.author: Gabe Rivers

data.text: Super Ground 27.5√ó2.25". I was running 2.8" before but found they were wider than I needed. These 2.25" are lighter at around 650g a tyre and roll very well on paved surfaces even with a lower air pressure. They fail on wet ground off road and would slide as they are more a dry gravel kind of tyre.
data.author: Peter Gostelow
Peter Gostelow

data.author: Peter Gostelow

data.text: Still never said why you "can't" go tubeless. Technology is changing, for the better. And I've never heard a good thing about Schwalbe tires personally.
data.author: Jeff Emrich

data.text: The Schwalbe Marathon Supremes. They‚Äôre the bomb, great on pavement, and I‚Äôve used them on gravel in 35x700. I have marathons in several variations but those are my favorites.
data.author: Jason Grace

data.text: It is a discontinued line of the marathon tyres. Whatever is available still on the internet...seems to come with tubeless technology. They look great though.

data.text: I sure hope not. If so I‚Äôll buy 4 sets per bike to stock for future use. They are the one tire I‚Äôd not want to ever be without.
data.author: Jason Grace

data.text: This tyre is not available in any of the EU shops I need to use.
data.author: Gabe Rivers

data.text: I‚Äôm sorry to hear that.
data.author: Jason Grace

data.text: it is okay. Thank you mate. It just makes everything complicated. :)
data.author: Gabe Rivers

data.text: The marathon is the classic
data.author: Rowan Springfield

data.text: Did you try the Schwalbe Marathon-series? They are for touring, but I mounted those tires on my cyclo-cross bike for commuting and never had any puncture since. They also last an eternity (between 10.000 and 20.000 km). I use the WTB Riddler on my gravelbike.
data.author: Bert Mannaert

data.text: How do you like the riddler's?
data.author: Scott Braithwaite

data.text: I like the way they roll. I have had some flat tyres when using the 38mm. Now I have a 45mm on and it seems to do a better job. This one has only gone flat once so far. That was because I jumped on a curb in the city (my mistake). I would recommend them for gravel and road combinations. As long as the gravel is not too rough. Excellent tyre.
data.author: Bert Mannaert

data.text: cool. Just got the marathon almotion 700*38c.
data.author: Gabe Rivers

data.text: Look underneath... I'm talking about the Riddler's (38 and 45mm) there üôÇ
data.author: Bert Mannaert

data.text: That one looks better equipped for an occasional off-road situation then the Marathon Plus I'm using. But to be fair, I'm only using my cross-bike to commute. Not much off-road in the middle of the city and if I fancy a few extra km's I'm able to do so. Great choice you made imho.
data.author: Bert Mannaert

data.text: I want to cycle on some of the eurovelo routes and I doubt they are all asphalt roads. I hope I will have the same opinion by the end of my trip.:)
data.author: Gabe Rivers

data.text: I'll keep my fingers crossed ;)
data.author: Bert Mannaert

data.text: Schwalbe has hundreds of models over the course of a couple years. I've used and liked their variously named racing tires in maximum sizes that still fit my road bike frames. 28mm are really 25mm, and get inflated to no more than 80psi for comfort and flat resistance. Marathons from Schwalbe remind of condoms introduced by Michelin, the first steel belted radial ones 40 years ago. puncture proof and grip when wet.
data.author: Harry Travis

data.text: Victory at ground zero
data.author: Massimo Amodeo

data.text: I was considering that one too...but they say that they wear out in no time.
data.author: Gabe Rivers

data.text: I used them as commuters for a long time
data.author: Massimo Amodeo

data.text: I‚Äôve been using the raceguard ones (with tubes) and I think I had maybe 1 puncture over thousands of kms. I use them mostly on roads and gravel, but I also do a fair amount of forest riding. As others have mentioned, Schwalbe Marathons are perfect if you really don‚Äôt want any punctures.
data.author: Kartolozzi Claire

data.text: Schwalbe tyres are great I use them for all my endurance races and have been very happy with the puncture protection to weight ratio. I sliced one open two years ago the kind of unlucky hole no amount of sealant can fix so popped a plug in and rode it for another 6 months. Why do people always blame the tyres for their choices or bad luck.
data.author: Luke Humphreys

data.text: I spent 1 month riding in scotland, didnt get a single puncture. Have had that bike since september, had no puncture, these tyres are sick
data.author: Don Julius

data.text: I was about to order them, but then it turns out G-ones are only produced TLR.

data.text: I use Marathons also great tyres

data.text: I am just checking those. They weight almost a kg per tyre. That is insane.
data.author: Gabe Rivers

data.text: blimy really they don‚Äôt seem that heavy to me
data.author: Tim Smith

data.text: I think I will go for the marathon almotion....700√ó38c. That seems to be the best option with tubes.
data.author: Gabe Rivers

data.text: they are the ones I use, I haven‚Äôt had a puncture in 2000 kilometres of riding, I‚Äôm sure mine aren‚Äôt as heavy as a kg
data.author: Tim Smith

data.text: There seems to be 2 types of almotion: V-Guard (with inner tubes,490grs) and MicroSkin (Tubeless, 625 grs). So, I have just bought the V-guard type.
data.author: Gabe Rivers

data.text: How does the almotion fare on wet road?
data.author: Gabe Rivers

data.text: I‚Äôve not had any problems, and they role along great, a few of my friends use them also
data.author: Tim Smith

data.text: Schwalbe makes a wide range of tires. It's a bit narrow minded to evaluate whole range based on results of one particular product. G One in this case. I find their website fairly helpful and informative if you want to compare different products. Personally I ride with Schwalbe Smart Sam Plus both on MTB and my gravel bike. They are resistant to punctures.
data.author: Edmundas Maiga

data.text: Copped a schwalbe marathon almotion (700x38) Haven't ridden it yet But had a mate do Indy pac on them and they were great
data.author: Callum Jefferies

data.text: You could Tey a tube with slime in it?
data.author: Gogs Nichol

data.text: I live in the land of goat heads, if you are running tubes I love the extra protection they give and I love them!!üëç
data.author: Rick Adler

data.text: Why can't you go tubeless? Also, use Tubolito City/tour puncture reisistant inner tubes. ‚Ç¨30 each
data.author: Adam Craig

data.text: just looking at those....30 euros each seems to be a bit excessive. Are they really that good? With a marathon almotion..wouldnt that be an overkill?
data.author: Gabe Rivers

data.text: you wanted puncture protection. No matter what way you look at it, it will be more expensive. Tubeless tyres cost more money than non tubeless. Sealant would cost money. Tough tyres cost more.
data.author: Adam Craig

data.text: I‚Äôm running Maxxis ramblers, 700x50c 60 TPI and no punctures. I bikepack and ride rocky fireroads that have big chunk gravel with lots of sharp edges and no issues Seem to roll well on road and have worked flawlessly now for over 7000km
data.author: Ken Boutilier

data.text: Try Schwalbe Marathon ,a few thousands km and 0 punctures .
data.author: Peia Ionut

data.text: yep. Just ordered the marathon almotion. :)
data.author: Gabe Rivers

data.text: marathons, even the skinny ones at 80+psi on the glass-strewn streets of London have been infallible for me so far. I don't even try to avoid glass anymore
data.author: Jamie Rowell

data.text: at the beginning I avoided the obstacles until I really tested them among the thorns in Albania and the pits in the Romanian asphalt, when I didn't even think that they wouldn't be pierced, they resisted brilliantly üôÇ. However, mine are very heavy.
data.author: Peia Ionut

data.text: I ride schwalbe racers - no punctures and they are fat and light
data.author: Kelcy Pegler

data.text: I'm sure someone has mentioned this because there are already a lot of comments (that I don't want to take the time to read), but Schwalbe is also well know in other segments of the sport for high performance tires (that have basically zero puncture protection). Just because you are familiar with one line of product a company does well doesn't mean they can't do other types of products. Look at Mercedes for example. They make some ridiculously fast race cars, but also slow bulletproof military vehicles.
data.author: Andy Outcalt

data.text: We just put on Schwalbe Marathon Plus Mtb tires. They offer all the same flat protection with a knobby tread. Thought they'd increase rolling resistance on pavement but no, they feel great. Ours are 26"x2.1.
data.author: Bobbie Gullickson

data.text: Build new wheels and go tubeless. If you refuse try Tannus Armor
data.author: Mike Chapman

data.text: Tubeless ready means you can also use it with inner tube. BTW, I misunderstood your post first, I thought you meant ‚Äú0 puncture-protection‚Äù, not the same as ‚Äú0-puncture protection‚Äù üòÇ
data.author: Amir Shahar

data.text: 700x40c Maxxis Ramblers have been a durable tire,I probably have thousands of miles on them between my wife‚Äôs bike and mine,I haven‚Äôt had a single flat,I think she‚Äôs had one but she weights quite a bit more than me
data.author: Gaston Arnold

data.text: I have exactly the same tyres and unfortunately my opinion is totally opposite to yours. I really think that I have some faulty batch... They are set up tubeless, yet I have punctures all the time. Sometimes they seal properly, sometimes it takes ages. One of the tyres was also leaking bubbles through sidewalls, but this eventually disappeared after 2-3 months.
data.author: Maciej Laskowski

data.text: we‚Äôve had three sets,so 6 tires and they‚Äôve all been great,one had a weepy sidewall until I got an actual decent ride in,once I got a 20 mile ride in it‚Äôs been solid
data.author: Gaston Arnold

data.text: Swallow World

data.text: got the almotion. :)
data.author: Gabe Rivers

data.text: This isn't the post I was looking to see. I just put the Schwalbe g one all around 700√ó40 tires on my new build. I set them up tubeless on some velocity cliffhanger rims. I guess I can post a review in a few months.
data.author: Douglas Miner

data.text: The sidewall on them isn't good at all.
data.author: Karen Hagan

data.text: I have used 2 sets of G One All Arounders tubeless with great success. Many miles of gravel and mixed surface bikepacking with zero issues, zero flats.
data.author: Brent Davis
